Lecture 01

NPM

NPM is the official package manager for Node.js.

NPM runs through the command line and manages dependencies for an application.

It also allows users to install Node.js applications that are available on the NPM registry.

For those who are familiar with dependency management tools and artifact repositories like Maven and Maven Central, NPM is similar.

One distinct difference between the two is that NPM does not manage build processes like Maven does.

Most, if not all, Node.js projects contain a package.json file in the root project.

This file exposes metadata about your application as well as its dependencies.


{
  "name": "my-project",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "My Cool Node Project",
  "main": "index.js",
  "author": "Sterling Archer",
  "dependencies": {
    "grunt": "0.4.2"
  }
}

When checking out a fresh project from GitHub, simply run 'npm install' to install all the dependencies required to run the project.

Bower

Bower is a package manager for front end dependencies.

We'll be using Bower in our project to manage libraries that we use in our Angular application, such as Angular itself.

Like NPM, Bower requires a bower.json file in the root of the project that specifies metadata about our project as well as its dependencies.


{
  "name": "my-project",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "My Cool Node Project",
  "author": "Pam Poovey",
  "dependencies": {
    "angular": "~1.2.14"
  }
}

When checking out a fresh project from GitHub, simply run 'bower install' to install all the client-side dependencies required by the client application.

Aside from using NPM and Bower to install our dependencies, we won't focus much on NPM or Bower in this training class.

You can visit the NPM and Bower websites to learn more about them.

bower.io

npmjs.org

Grunt

Grunt is a JavaScript Task Runner.

We'll be using Grunt to automate many of the project build tasks associated with a web application.

The less work we have to do when performing repetitive tasks like minification, compilation, unit testing, linting, etc., the easier our life becomes.

Grunt, by itself, is a framework designed for running tasks. It also provides a lot of common utilities needed for performing things like filesystem operations.

We'll be using Grunt plugins created by individuals and the community that help automate tasks that are specific to our application.
